attributes.title: Economic models for estimating cost-effectiveness of CPAP treatment in OSAS patients: a scoping review.

q1.value: Economic models for estimating cost-effectiveness of CPAP treatment in OSAS patients: a scoping review.

q3.value: CPAP is widely considered the gold standard treatment for moderate to severe OSAS cases. This fact is based on several studies assessing the efficacy, effectiveness and safety of CPAP treatment. CPAP has also been demonstrated to be a cost-effective treatment but it is not fully covered or reimbursed in many countries, such as Brazil.

q4.value: The hypothesis that justifies this study is that economic models focusing on estimating cost-effectiveness of CPAP treatment are very distinct in regards of the choice of health outcomes, sources of costs, and time horizon, among other assumptions of the model. The objective of this study is to summarize the parameters used in previous economic models by the conduction of a scoping review.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Scoping review

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: We have conducted systematic searches in PubMed and CRD to search for partial or full economic studies. At the time of the registration, we were at the beginning of the data extraction stage.

question.value: We will select studies fulfilling the following inclusion criteria: partial or full economic studies focusing on CPAP treatment or on ways of delivering care for CPAP treated patients, regardless of the type of comparator and the source of data (piggyback evaluation, modeling, mixed approach). Exclusion criteria are: studies focusing on diagnostic strategies for OSAS rather than on CPAP treatment.

q13.value: Not applicable. This is not a primary study.

•	Total cost (comparator)

•	ICER (intervention to comparator)
•	Willingness to pay	
•	Monetary Net benefit

•	Conclusion
Data extraction will include all variables listed above.
Not applicable. No quantitative synthesis is planned.

attributes.title: Time to Stop Worrying: A Correlational Study on Individualist versus Collectivist Time Perspectives and Anxiety

q1.value: Time to Stop Worrying: A Correlational Study on Individualist Versus Collectivist Time Perspectives and Anxiety

q3.value: Time perspective has increasingly been seen to play a central role in many domains of psychology, therefore, the value of including time perspective as a variable in new research should be promoted (Zimbardo & Boyd, 1999). This present research intends to explore three major variables including time perspectives, level of individualism versus collectivism, and anxiety. The sample population anticipated for this study will include participants of various places of origin to gather a sufficient amount of data on what time perspectives are predominant in participants that are more individualistic or collectivistic. Subsequently, I will assess whether entire people groups lean towards individualism or collectivism. Furthermore, I will investigate how these constructs are related to anxiety. A survey will be administered electronically to participants to measure the three variables listed above.

q4.value:
RQ1: Do individualistic/collectivistic participants have one predominant time perspective?
RQ2: Do entire people groups lean towards either individualism or collectivism?
RQ3: Do levels of individualism/collectivism correlate with levels of anxiety?
RQ4: Do different time perspectives correlate with levels of anxiety? 

From these three research questions, we derive 9 main hypotheses: 

RQ1 Hypotheses: 

Hypothesis 1: Individualistic participants will have a future time perspective.
Hypothesis 2: Collectivistic participants will have a past time perspective.

RQ2 Hypothesis:

Hypothesis 3: Participants of the same country of origin will have the same tendency towards either individualism or collectivism.

RQ3 Hypothesis:

Hypothesis 4: Participants with a tendency towards individualism will display a higher level of anxiety than participants with a tendency towards collectivism.

RQ4 Hypotheses:

Hypothesis 5: Anxiety will show a positive correlation with past negative time perspective.
Hypothesis 6: Anxiety will show a positive correlation with present fatalistic time perspective.
Hypothesis 7: Anxiety will show a negative correlation with past positive time perspective.
Hypothesis 8: Anxiety will show a negative correlation with present hedonistic time perspective.
Hypothesis 9: Anxiety will show a negative correlation with future time perspective.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is correlational due to its intent to assess relationships between variables that are naturally occurring. This study will not conclude in any causal claim; but, an understanding of the strength and direction of correlations between variables will be emphasized. I will not be manipulating any variables, but instead measuring participant’s scores in three primary areas.

q9.value: No randomization will be used in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected by means of a survey distributed through an online platform as well as through an email link to individuals abroad in order to reach a wide variety of participants. The only criteria for the demographics of participants is that they are over the age of 18 to ensure more personality development and full understanding of the questions being asked of them. Amazon Mechanical Turk will serve as the host site for this survey, as it is imperative that I gather data on an abundance of people.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 400 participants. With a budget of $300 and a compensation of $.75 per participant on MTurk, we expect around 350-400 participants. After releasing the survey to organizations abroad, it is expected to receive responses from around 50 more participants.

q14.value: It will be necessary to obtain a large sample size that is representative of the world's population, seeing as this study is cross-cultural. Due to funding, we will only be able to reach around 350-400 participants from MTurk, yet will consider administering the study to international organizations if the sample is not representative enough.

q15.value: We plan to collect data through MTurk until we reach 400 participants, which is expected to take no more than a week.

question.value:
Our major measurable variables include time perspectives, individualism versus collectivism, and anxiety. The survey will contain three scales to measure these variables. The first is the Zimbardo Time Perspective Inventory (ZTPI), to measure their central time perspective. The ZTPI is made up of 58 items that are answered on a 5-point Likert scale with 1 being “very untrue” and 5 being “very true".
		
The second section will include the Individualism and Collectivism Scale (INDCOL) which is designed to measure four dimensions of collectivism and individualism. This scale consists of 17 items measured on 9-point Likert scale with 1 being “never” and 9 being “always".

The third section of the survey will be a trait anxiety scale that will include items from the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16PF) and the HEXACO Personality Inventory (HEXACO). This scale includes 11 items measured on a 5-point Likert scale with 1 being “strongly disagree” and 5 being “strongly agree”.

Pearson Correlation Coefficients will be used to assess the following correlations: Participant level of individualism and each of the 5 time perspectives, Participant level of collectivism and each of the 5 time perspectives, Participant level of individualism and level of anxiety, Participant level of collectivism and level of anxiety, Participants with past negative time perspective and their level of anxiety, Participants with past positive time perspective and their level of anxiety, Participants with present fatalistic time perspective and their level of anxiety, Participants with present hedonistic time perspective and their level of anxiety, Participants with future time perspective and their level of anxiety. We will also assess whether there are differences found between groups of participant from different countries using an ANOVA. Descriptive statistics will be obtained from the demographic information provided from the survey.

q21.value:
We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggests that the results are significantly different between groups. 
The Tukey post-hoc test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
All participants are required to complete all portions the survey in order to advance throughout the survey and submit the survey. We have included quality check items throughout the survey, as well, so if any participant fails one of these items, their data will be removed from the analyses. Outliers will be included in the analyses. 
Data will only be collected from participants over the age of 18 years old.

q23.value: We will only complete relevant correlational analyses per completed survey portion.

name.value: IH and specific person perception: standardized testing

sample.value: We will aim to collect 300 participants on AMT prior to any exclusions.

analyses.value:
We will average the following variables into a composite: unintelligent, irrational, and ignorant. And we will average the following variables into a composite: bad moral character, unethical, and immoral. We will correlate intellectual humility with these composites. We will keep the other three DVs separate as one shot items. We will correlate intellectual humility with each of these. 

Then, we will compute multiple regressions with demographics and political variables along with intellectual humility (and interaction terms) in predicting all the DVs and the composites in separate models.

outliers.value: We have two attention checks. Participants who fail either one will be excluded. The first attention check asks participants to provide a particular response to one question within the intellectual humility survey. The other attention check occurs at the end. Participants will be asked the following: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” They responded by selecting one of the following: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants were ensured that their responses would not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value:
Participants will be asked to judge another specific person who chooses the other possible position about  standardized testing on the following:
-unintelligent (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
Participants will also be asked whether they would be willing to befriend the other person who chooses the other position, "friend" the other person on social media, or "follow" the other person on social media.

conditions.value: No conditions to which participants will be assigned.

hypothesis.value: Are those lower in intellectual humility (relative to higher in intellectual humility) more likely to see a specific person who disagrees with them on a political issue (standardized testing in public schools) as more unintelligent, irrational, and ignorant? Are those lower in intellectual humility (relative to higher in intellectual humility) more likely to see someone who disagrees with them on a political issue as more immoral, unethical, and of worse moral character? Are those lower in intellectual humility (relative to higher in intellectual humility) more likely to report that they would not befriend, friend, or follow someone who disagrees with them on a political issue? Do these effects persist even after statistically controlling for demographics variables, political party affiliation, the extent to which participants identity as liberal or conservative, and the centrality of political party affiliation to identity?

attributes.title: HOW CAN WE REDUCE FEAR IN PEOPLE WITH KNEE OSTEOARTHRITIS? A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW

q1.value: HOW CAN WE REDUCE FEAR IN PEOPLE WITH KNEE OSTEOARTHRITIS? A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW

q2.value: Javier Martinez-Calderon, Mar Flores-Cortes, Alejandro Luque-Suarez, Jose Miguel Morales-Asencio

q3.value: Knee osteoarthritis is a leading cause of global chronic pain and disability. Knee osteoarthritis patients with greater levels of fear report worse postural stability, lack of knee confidence, greater disability, and more pain.

q4.value: The aim of this systematic review was twofold: to (1) explore which interventions reduce fear in people with knee osteoarthritis, and (2) assess reporting of interventions designed to decrease fear.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of randomized trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
We searched CENTRAL, CINAHL, EMBASE, PEDro, PsycINFO, PubMed, and SPORTDiscus from inception up to November 2019. 
Eligibility Criteria
The inclusion criteria were: 
1.	Studies: trials.
2.	Participants: adults with knee osteoarthritis.
3.	Interventions: conservative and/or surgical interventions designed to reduce fear.
4.	Outcome: fear measured as a primary or secondary outcome.

The exclusion criteria were:
1.	Knee pain as a result of any other acute or chronic condition
2.	Studies with animals.

Trial Selection
Potential articles were screened by title and abstract. Then, we screened full-text when  trial selection was unclear after reading the title and abstract. We resolved any disagreements via consensus or a third reviewer, if required.
Data Extraction
The following information will be extracted from every included study: study (year and country) and participant characteristics (age, sex, and pain duration); setting; fear details; covariates in the adjustment of treatment effects; and main findings of every included trial. Any disagreements were resolved via consensus.

q13.value: The sample is of people with knee osteoarthritis. We did not calculate the sample size due to this is a systematic review design.

question.value: Fear assessed as a primary or secondary outcome. The following fear constructs were considered: fear about pain, pain-related anxiety, fear of falling, fear-avoidance beliefs, fear of movement, and kinesiophobia.

We plan to conduct meta-analyses of effect estimates for different intervention categories and fear outcomes (i.e. psychological intervention and kinesiophobia). If meta-analyses cannot be carried out, for example, due to a huge heterogeneity across the included studies, we summarise data using a narrative synthesis. We used the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool 2 to assess the risk of bias. We used the GRADE approach to evaluate the certainty of the evidence.

Are those lower in intellectual humility (relative to higher in intellectual humility) more likely to see someone who disagrees with them on a political issue as more immoral, unethical, and of worse moral character? Are those lower in intellectual humility (relative to higher in intellectual humility) more likely to report that they would not befriend, friend, or follow someone who disagrees with them on a political issue? Do these effects persist even after statistically controlling for demographics variables, political party affiliation, the extent to which participants identity as liberal or conservative, and the centrality of political party affiliation to identity?

registration_responses.name: IH and specific person perception
registration_responses.sample: We will aim to collect 300 participants on AMT prior to any exclusions.
registration_responses.analyses:
We will average the following variables into a composite: unintelligent, irrational, and ignorant. And we will average the following variables into a composite: bad moral character, unethical, and immoral. We will correlate intellectual humility with these composites. We will keep the other three DVs separate as one shot items. We will correlate intellectual humility with each of these. 

Then, we will compute multiple regressions with demographics and political variables along with intellectual humility (and interaction terms) in predicting all the DVs and the composites in separate models.
registration_responses.outliers: We have two attention checks. Participants who fail either one will be excluded. The first attention check asks participants to provide a particular response to one question within the intellectual humility survey. The other attention check occurs at the end. Participants will be asked the following: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” They responded by selecting one of the following: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants were ensured that their responses would not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.
registration_responses.dependent:
Participants will be asked to judge another specific person who chooses the other possible position about  gun control on the following:
-unintelligent (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-irrational (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-ignorant (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-bad moral character (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-unethical (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
-immoral (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
Participants will also be asked whether they would be willing to befriend the other person who chooses the other position, "friend" the other person on social media, or "follow" the other person on social media.

attributes.title: The effect of smileys on consumer behavior

q1.value: The effect of smileys in hedonic and utilitarian product reviews on consumer behavior

q3.value:
Smileys have been developed as the digital counterpart to a real smile. Thereby, they allow the composer of a digital text to convey their emotions non-verbally. Though the use of smileys in computer-mediated-communication (CMC) has proliferated, there is surprisingly little research on the effects of smileys on consumer behavior. This is remarkable, especially with the rise of internet shopping which requires consumers to rely more and more on CMC to communicate their experiences related to consumption in online customer reviews (OCRs), also called 'electronic word-of-mouth' (eWOM). Although recent research suggests that smileys enhance the perceived valence of text messages and lead to emotional contagion, their role within OCRs remains unclear. 

An important distinction in OCRs needs to be made between hedonic products, products that are purchased and consumed for fun, and utilitarian products, products that are purchased and consumed for their functionality.

The present study investigates whether smileys in OCRs affect the affective reaction of a person to an OCR, how credible a person perceives the OCR to be, and the intention to purchase the product described in the OCR. Given the affective nature of hedonic and the cognitive nature of utilitarian purchasing decisions, purchase intentions for hedonic and utilitarian products should be affected by different mediating variables, which are differently affected by smileys. 

It is expected that the use of smileys in hedonic product reviews will enhance experienced affect, which in turn is expected to influence purchase intentions. In contrast, smileys are expected to have a different effect on utilitarian purchase intentions, as they reduce the perceived credibility of the review. To test this, participants will be presented with positive and negative OCRs of hedonic and utilitarian products that contain a smiley or not. Their experienced affect, the perceived credibility of the OCR, and their purchase intentions will be assessed.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Smileys will increase the perceived valence of an OCR. Therefore, participants will perceive positive OCRs including smileys as more positive and negative OCRs including smileys as more negative than comparable OCRs with only plain text.

Hypothesis 2: Smileys are seen as inappropriate in the more formal context of an OCR. Therefore, using smileys (in either positive or negative OCRs) will reduce the perceived credibility of the review.
 
Hypothesis 3: Purchase intentions for hedonic and utilitarian products are based on different considerations. Whereas the intention to purchase hedonic products is primarily guided by the anticipated joy of consuming the product, for utilitarian products usually more objective arguments are used to justify purchases. Since smileys enhance the perceived affect of texts, for hedonic prodcuts positive OCRs including a smiley should lead to higher purchase intentions than plain text positive OCRs. Conversely, negative OCRs of hedonic products including a smiley should lead to lower purchase intentions than plain text negative OCRs. For utilitarian purchase intentions, on the other hand, smileys reduce the credibility of OCRs and therefore positive OCRs of utilitarian products including a smiley should lead to lower purchase intentions compared to plain text positive OCRs because a less credible positive review is a weaker argument for purchasing something. For negative OCRs of utilitarian products, however, including a smiley increases purchase intentions compared to plain text negative OCRs, because a less credible negative review affects purchase intentions less strongly than a high credible negative OCR. 

Hypotheses 4 and 5: The effects of smileys on purchase intentions should not be direct, but rather be mediated by the affective reaction to an OCR (for hedonic products: Hypothesis 4) or the credibility of an OCR (for utilitarian products: Hypothesis 5).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The experiment will have a 2 (Review Valence: Positive vs. Negative) x 2 (Smileys: Present vs. Not) x 2 (Product Type: Hedonic vs. Utilitarian) within-subjects design.

q9.value: The sequence of all trials and the allocation of the stimuli to the cells of the design will be randomized anew for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited by means of Prolific Academic. The sample will mostly contain US and UK citizens, as only people who are fluent in English are eligible for participation. Participants will be paid a small monetary compensation for agreeing to participate in a study that will take around 5-10 minutes to complete.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 78 participants.

q14.value: The power analysis for this study was based on very comparable previous studies investigating the effects of smileys on the perceived valence of text messages. The lowest effect size observed in these studies was dz = 0.45 – for the comparison between affective reactions to plain negative text messages and negative text messages including a smiley. To be able to detect such an effect size with a power of (1-β) = 0.80 in a paired samples t-test, N = 41 participants are needed. However, in the current study eight such comparisons are planned (differences between plain messages and messages with a smiley on affective reactions and credibility separate for positive and negative OCRs (four tests), plus differences between plain messages and messages with a smiley on purchase intentions for hedonic and utilitarian products, separately for positive and negative OCRs, also four tests). Thus, to achieve a power of (1-β) = 0.80 for the whole set of eight hypothesis tests, every individual test should exhibit a power of (1-β) = 0.975, because 0.975^6 = 0.817.

q15.value: We will stop collecting data as soon as we reach our target sample size of 78 participants.

question.value:
Product type:
Based on a pre-test (see also this project), we identified 8 clearly hedonic and 8 clearly utilitarian products, which will serve as the stimuli for this study. Product type will be manipulated within-subjects (hedonic vs. utilitarian).

Review valence:
Based on a pre-test (see also this project), we created a positive and a negative version of an OCR for each of the products. Review valence will be manipulated within-subjects (positive vs. negative).

Smileys:
Smileys will be manipulated by including a smiley in half of the OCRs whereas the remaining are presented as plain text. The smiley 'Smiling Face With Smiling Eyes' (U+1F60A) will be used in positive reviews and the smiley 'Disappointed Face' (U+1F61E) will be used in negative reviews.

Affective reactions:
In order to measure the experienced affective feelings, we adopted two scale items used in previous research. More specifically, affect will be measured by asking participants ‘How do you feel after reading this review?’ and ‘How positively do you rate the review?’. Both questions will be measured on a seven-point scale going from 1 (“very negative”) to 7 (“very positive”).

Credibility:
In order to measure the perceived credibility, we adopted two scale items used in previous research. Participants will be asked to indicate to what extent they agree with the following two statements: ‘I think this review is credible’ and ‘I think this review is convincing’. Both statements will be rated on a seven-point scale going from 1 (“strongly disagree”) to 7 (“strongly agree”).

Purchase intentions:
Purchase intentions after reading the review will be measured by adopting one item from previous research. Participants are asked to indicate to what extent they agree with the statement: ‘It is very likely that I will buy the product’ on a seven-point scale ranging from 1 (“strongly disagree”) to 7 (“strongly agree”).

Scores on the individual items comprising the measured variables of this study will be averaged to form one index for the respective variables, which will be compared between the different cells of the design.

All analyses will be conducted using SPSS and the PROCESS Macro for SPSS. 

Hypotheses 1-3 will be tested using three-way repeated-measures ANOVAs on the dependent variables Affect, Credibility, and Purchase Intentions, respectively, with the independent variables Smiley, Review Valence, and Product Type. Paired samples t-tests will be used for the post-hoc tests of the simple effects.

Hypothesis 1 concerns the effect of smileys on affective reactions towards OCRs. It is predicted that smileys will amplify both positive reactions towards positive OCRs and negative reactions towards negative OCRs. This pattern corresponds to the two-way interaction between the factors of Review Valence and Smileys. The simple effects of smileys on affective reactions will be tested separately for positive and negative messages.

Hypothesis 2 concerns the effect of smileys on perceived credibility. The hypothesis that smileys lower perceived credibility corresponds to a main effect of Smiley. Although no interaction is predicted, the same post-hoc tests as for affective reactions will be computed.

Hypothesis 3 concerns the effect of smileys on purchase intentions. It is predicted that for hedonic products, smileys increase purchase intentions (compared to plain text) for positive OCRs, and reduce purchase intentions for negative OCRs. For utilitarian products, the opposite is predicted: Smileys reduce purchase intentions for positive OCRs, and increase purchase intentions for negative OCRs. This pattern corresponds to a three-way interaction within the ANOVA. All individual contrasts will be tested in post-hoc tests.

Hypotheses 4-5 will be tested in two separate moderated mediation frameworks for hedonic and utilitarian products, respectively. For both products, the models will include Smileys as the independent variable (contrast-coded: -0.5 for plain text OCRs and 0.5 for OCRs with smileys), two parallel continuous mediators (credibility and affective reactions), Review Valence as the moderator (contrast-coded: -0.5 for negative OCRs and 0.5 for positive OCRs) and Purchase Intentions as the continuous criterion. 

For hedonic products, the moderator will affect the path from the independent variable to the mediator (model 7 in PROCESS). Both for positive and negative OCRs, a mediation of the effect of smileys on purchase intention via Affect is predicted. However, the sign of these indirect effects will differ: For positive OCRs, smileys will positively predict affective reactions to the OCR, which will positively predict purchase intentions. Thus, the overall indirect effect should have a positive sign. For negative OCRs, on the other hand, the relation between smileys and affective reactions will be negative. Since affect will still positively predict purchase intentions, this indirect effect will have a negative sign. No effect via Credibility is predicted for hedonic products.

For utilitarian products, on the other hand, the moderator will affect the path from the mediator to the criterion (model 14 in PROCESS). Both for positive and negative OCRs, a mediation of the effect of smileys on purchase intention via Credibility is predicted. However, the sign of these indirect effects will differ: For all OCRs, smileys will negatively predict credibility. However, while for positive OCRs credibility positively predicts purchase intentions, for negative OCRs the opposite is true. Thus, the overall indirect effect for positive OCRs should have a negative sign, whereas for negative OCRs, on the other hand, this indirect effect should have a positive sign.

q20.value: The coding of the manipulated variables is described above.

q21.value:
For hypotheses 1-3, we will use the standard criterion for significance of p = .05. 

For the planned post-hoc tests, the same criterion, but in a one-sided test will be used.

For the mediation analysis (Hypotheses 4-5), instead of testing significance, regression weights and 95% CIs will be estimated using 5,000 bootstrap samples. It will be concluded that effects are significant within this framework if the confidence interval does not include 0.

q22.value: Missing data will be excluded from the analysis.

q23.value: Missing data will be deleted list-wise.

q24.value: In exploratory analyses, we might assess the effects of our review valence manipulation on credibility (main effect of review valence in the corresponding ANOVA) and we will test whether negative reviews also directly influence purchasing intentions. Furthermore, we might inspect whether online-shopping frequency affects the observed relations.

q25.value: The references for all measures will be uploaded to this OSF project, where we will also make all of our materials available.

summary.value: This is an update of the previous registration. It follows the fact that we realised that the textual corpus  we worked with is substantially incomplete. Therefore we decided to build a new dataset and a set of new tools for working with it (new lemmatization, new temporal metadata). The new dataset consists from 1458 deduplicated documents and 34,589,083 words. As in the case of the previous dataset, we will work only with a subselection of these, i.e. only with documents which are (1) at least to some extent datable (on the century basis), (2) which emerged before or at the year 400 CE, and (3) which might be classified as being either of "christian" or "pagan" provenience (i.e. not "jewish"). There is at least 867 of such documents, but perhaps even more than that. The uploaded scripts represent a snapshot of our workflow before we started to analyse these new data in respect to our research question.

attributes.title: Detecting concealed familiarity using eye movements: The effect of leakage of mock-crime details to innocents

q1.value: Detecting concealed familiarity using eye movements: The effect of leakage of mock-crime details to innocents

q2.value: Ine van der Cruyssen, Bruno verschuere, Yoni Pertzov, Yoni Pertzov lab, Gershon Ben-Shakhar

q3.value:
Can eye movements reveal crime enactment? 
In this study, 48 participants will be randomly assigned to either the mock crime condition (e.g., steal a credit card from a mailbox) or an innocent condition (i.e., carry out their normal activities on campus). When they return, all participants will be informed that there has been a crime on campus. While informing participants, two randomly selected crime related items will be verbally leaked (e.g., “when you were gone, a credit card has been stolen from Prof. Verschuere’s mailbox”), while the other two crime-related items remain non-leaked. Afterward, all participants will do a short term memory task, using the design proposed by Lancry-Dayan et al. (2018). In this computerized task, participants have to decide whether a single presented image also appeared in the previous display of four images. We will manipulate the presence of a mock crime-related image among the four images on the 4-display and on the single display. Based on participants' gaze behavior towards these crime-related images, we will examine whether guilty participants can be distinguished from innocent participants, and to what extent this is also possible for leaked items for which guilty and innocent participants share crime knowledge.

q4.value:
We expect a difference in eye-movements for guilty participants as compared to innocent ones. 

Participants who committed the mock crime are familiar with the crime-related items and are expected to show an initial (1-1000 ms) preference and a late (1000-5000 ms) avoidance of the crime-related items in the 4-display. We also expect a longer viewing time, higher accuracy rates and faster response time when familiar crime details are presented to guilty participants during the single display.

Participants who did not commit this crime do not recognize the crime-related items and are expected not to show this typical eye-gazing pattern towards crime-related items as compared to foils. 

Leakage is an exploratory variable, so we have no concrete hypotheses for this variable. We will test if gaze deployment towards leaked information is similar to gaze towards a crime-related item or towards an unfamiliar item.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value:
In this study, we will use two experimenters. 

The first experimenter tells the participants whether he/she should commit a mock crime or do their normal business on campus. Therefore, this first experiment is not blind. 

After the first phase, a second experimenter enters the lab and carries out the rest of the experiment. This is experimenter is not aware of the assigned condition.

question.value:
The design is mixed. 

Crime enactment is a between-subjects variable with two levels. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the guilty or the innocent condition. 

Leakage is a within-subjects variable with two levels (leaked vs. non-leaked). Two out of four crime-related items will be randomly selected and verbally leaked to each participant. 

Item is a within-subjects variable with two levels (crime-related vs foil). The items in the short term memory task can either be crime-related or foils.

Phase is a within-subjects variable with two levels (first phase 1-1000ms vs second phase 1000-5000ms). We compare the eye-movements during the first phase with the eye-movements during the second phase. 

This results in a 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 mixed design.

q9.value: Three pseudo-random vectors consisting of the numbers 1-16 will be created in R (length = 16 participants), indicating the condition (guilty vs. innocent and which crime-related items should be leaked) and profile (we created four profiles to counterbalance the crime-related items, e.g., the item to be stolen).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants with normal or corrected to normal vision will be recruited by the online recruitment system of the University of Amsterdam. They will receive either credit points or money for participating.

q14.value: Lancry-Dayan et al. (2018) found a large effect size of partial η²= .719. To provide for a more conservative estimate, we aim for 90% power to detect a moderate effect (f = 0.25). For a 2 (group: guilty vs. innocent, between-subjects) by 2 (leakage: leaked vs. non-leaked, within-subjects) by 2 (item: crime-related vs foil, within-subjects) by 2 (phase: first phase 1-1000ms vs second phase 1000-5000ms, within-subjects) mixed ANOVA, with alpha = .05, this means that we should include N = 20. To anticipate exclusions, allow exploratory analyses, and make sure that we have an equal amount of participants in each condition, and for each profile, we will test N = 48.

q15.value: We will stop testing when we have reached 48 participants.

question.value:
Crime enactment: 2 between-subjects levels: mock crime condition and innocent condition. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the guilty or the innocent condition. 

Leakage: 2 within-subjects levels: leaked item and non-leaked item. Two out of four crime-related items will be randomly selected and verbally leaked to each participant. 

Item: 2 within-subjects levels: crime-related and foil. For each participant, there are 4 crime-related items and 28 foils. In 50% of the 4-display trials, one crime-related item and 3 foils will be presented. In the other 50%, only foils will be presented. Also in the single display, 50% of the displays contain a crime-related item. In the single display, 50% of the trials contain an item that also appeared in the 4-display (trials on which the participant should answer "yes"). In the other 50%, the single display contains an item that did not appear in the 4-display (trials on which the participant should answer "no").

Phase: 2 within-subjects levels:  first phase (1-1000ms) and second phase (1000-5000ms) of the 4-display

During the parallel display: gaze dwell time during the first phase (1–1000 ms) and the second phase (1000–5000 ms), number of visits, and the total number of fixations on each image.

During the single display: the mean fixation duration, the response time (RT), and the accuracy on the short term memory task

Post-experiment: age, sex, study/work, remembered mock crime-related items

The analyses of the data will be similar to those in Lancry-Dayan et al. (2018).

- Main analysis
To examine whether guilty participants show a larger initial preference and late avoidance towards crime-related items than innocents in the 4-display, even when crime-related items were leaked, we will conduct an ANOVA with three within-subject factors (item [crime-related vs not crime-related], phase [first phase 1-1000ms vs second phase 1000-5000ms] and leakage [leaked vs not leaked] ) and one between-subject factor (guilt [guilty vs innocent]) and dwell time as the dependent variable.  

- Visit analysis
On each trial, the number of visits to the crime-related item and the foils will be calculated. For both the 4- and the single display, we will compare the number of overall fixations by the use of a 2 (item: crime-related vs foil, within) x 2 (leakage: leaked vs non-leaked, within) x 2 (guilt: guilty vs innocent, between) mixed ANOVA

- Performance on the short term memory task
Participants reaction time and accuracy will be compared when there was a crime-related item vs foil in the single display, using a 2 (item: crime-related vs foil, within) x 2 (leakage: leaked vs non-leaked, within) x 2 (guilt: guilty vs innocent, between) mixed ANOVA

q20.value: Eye movement data will be parsed into saccades and fixations using the Eyelink's standard parser configuration (i.e., samples of which the deviation of consecutive samples exceeded 30°/s velocity or 8000°/s² acceleration will be defined as saccades, time intervals in between saccades will be defined as fixations).

q21.value: We will use the standard α=.05 criterion.

q22.value:
Exclusions:
- Not following instructions (e.g., not enacting the requested activity)
- Technical error during data acquisition
- Calibration problems (e.g., due to light-colored or Asian eyes)
- Participants who underperform on the working memory task (less than 60% of the trials correct)
- Participants of the mock crime condition who don't remember at least 1 leaked and 1 non-leaked crime-related item in the post-study memory test

q23.value: If more than 30% of eye movement data is missing (e.g., because of a technical error), we will exclude this participant from all analyses.

registration_responses.q1: Detecting concealed familiarity using eye movements: The effect of leakage of mock-crime details to innocents
registration_responses.q2: Ine van der Cruyssen, Bruno verschuere, Yoni Pertzov, Yoni Pertzov lab, Gershon Ben-Shakhar
registration_responses.q3:
Can eye movements reveal crime enactment? 
In this study, 48 participants will be randomly assigned to either the mock crime condition (e.g., steal a credit card from a mailbox) or an innocent condition (i.e., carry out their normal activities on campus). When they return, all participants will be informed that there has been a crime on campus. While informing participants, two randomly selected crime related items will be verbally leaked (e.g., “when you were gone, a credit card has been stolen from Prof. Verschuere’s mailbox”), while the other two crime-related items remain non-leaked. Afterward, all participants will do a short term memory task, using the design proposed by Lancry-Dayan et al. (2018). In this computerized task, participants have to decide whether a single presented image also appeared in the previous display of four images. We will manipulate the presence of a mock crime-related image among the four images on the 4-display and on the single display. Based on participants' gaze behavior towards these crime-related images, we will examine whether guilty participants can be distinguished from innocent participants, and to what extent this is also possible for leaked items for which guilty and innocent participants share crime knowledge.

Participants who did not commit this crime do not recognize the crime-related items and are expected not to show this typical eye-gazing pattern towards crime-related items as compared to foils.
